meta.notes: 100 neurovascular & stroke MCQs; difficulty 20% easy, 30% moderate, 50% hard; correct options balanced across A-D.

questions.stem: Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery classically causes which deficit pattern?
questions.explanation: Left MCA supplies lateral frontal/parietal/temporal cortex: contralateral face/arm > leg weakness and, in dominant hemisphere, aphasia.

questions.stem: Which artery primarily supplies the medial frontal and parietal lobes including the paracentral lobule?
questions.explanation: ACA perfuses medial hemispheric surfaces (leg motor/sensory).

questions.stem: A lesion of the lateral medulla most commonly results from occlusion of which artery?
questions.explanation: Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome typically due to PICA occlusion.

questions.stem: Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing suggests infarct in which vascular territory?
questions.explanation: PCA infarcts of the occipital cortex produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia; macular sparing can occur due to dual supply.

questions.stem: A pure motor lacunar stroke most often localizes to the:
questions.explanation: Lacunes in the posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis commonly produce pure motor hemiparesis.

questions.stem: Lateral medullary syndrome classically includes which combination?
options: Ipsilateral tongue weakness, contralateral vibration loss
Ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss, contralateral body pain/temp loss, ataxia, Horner
Contralateral face and body pain/temp loss with hemiparesis
questions.explanation: Wallenberg: ipsilateral facial pain/temp (SpV), contralateral body pain/temp (STT), ipsi ataxia (ICP), nucleus ambiguus signs, ipsi Horner.

questions.stem: Which test is most sensitive for detection of acute ischemic stroke within the first hour?
questions.explanation: DWI MRI detects cytotoxic edema early; CT is used first to exclude hemorrhage but may be initially normal.

questions.stem: A left superior division MCA stroke most likely causes:
options: Broca aphasia with right arm weakness
questions.explanation: Left superior division supplies inferior frontal gyrus; Broca aphasia and contralateral face/arm weakness.

questions.stem: A stroke in the PPRF or abducens nucleus on the right causes which gaze deficit?
options: Failure to look right with right gaze palsy
Failure to look left with left gaze palsy
questions.explanation: Right PPRF/VI lesion causes ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (can't look right).

questions.stem: Which structure carries pain and temperature from the body and crosses near the anterior commissure of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: STT fibers cross in the anterior white commissure and ascend contralaterally.

questions.stem: A right MCA inferior division stroke typically causes which cortical syndrome?
questions.explanation: Non-dominant inferior parietal/temporal lesions produce hemispatial neglect.

questions.stem: Occlusion of the anterior choroidal artery most classically produces:
options: Contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and homonymous hemianopia
questions.explanation: Anterior choroidal supplies posterior limb of internal capsule, optic tract/radiations—triad may occur.

questions.stem: Locked-in syndrome is most commonly due to infarction of:
questions.explanation: Basilar occlusion causing bilateral ventral pontine infarction leads to quadriplegia with preserved consciousness/vertical eye movements.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old with neck trauma presents with ipsilateral Horner syndrome and posterior circulation symptoms. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Vertebral dissection causes posterior circulation ischemia; carotid dissection classically causes painful Horner + anterior circulation TIAs.

questions.stem: A left PCA infarct involving the splenium is MOST associated with:
questions.explanation: Dominant occipital (PCA) with splenial involvement disconnects visual input to language areas—alexia without agraphia.

questions.stem: Weber syndrome (midbrain) arises from PCA branches and produces:
options: Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiparesis
questions.explanation: Weber: ventral midbrain lesion affecting CN III fascicles and corticospinal tract.

questions.stem: Paramedian thalamic infarcts due to artery of Percheron occlusion typically present with:
options: Bilateral thalamic infarcts with decreased arousal and memory deficits
questions.explanation: Artery of Percheron supplies bilateral paramedian thalami → somnolence, memory/behavioral changes.

questions.stem: A small deep infarct causing pure sensory stroke localizes best to:
questions.explanation: VPL thalamic lacunes produce pure sensory deficits.

questions.stem: Which imaging finding most strongly suggests early ischemia on non-contrast CT?
options: Hyperdense MCA sign, insular ribbon sign, sulcal effacement
questions.explanation: Hyperdense artery and early parenchymal hypodensity/effacement suggest acute ischemia.

questions.stem: NIHSS items primarily weight which deficits?
options: Language, neglect, visual fields, motor strength
questions.explanation: NIHSS emphasizes cortical signs and motor/visual deficits; ataxia has limited weighting.

questions.stem: A patient with right MCA syndrome has eyes deviated to the right and left-sided weakness. This gaze deviation localizes to:
options: Frontal eye fields in right hemisphere
questions.explanation: Cortical FEF lesions cause eyes to deviate toward the lesion (away from weakness).

questions.stem: Which stroke mechanism best explains multiple small cortical infarcts in varying vascular territories on MRI?
questions.explanation: Shower emboli from the heart often produce multi-territory cortical infarcts.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old with atrial fibrillation presents within 90 minutes of onset with disabling left hemiparesis. Best initial therapy?
questions.explanation: Within 4.5 hours, IV thrombolysis is indicated if criteria are met; anticoagulation is started later.

questions.stem: Which sign suggests cerebellar infarct needing urgent neurosurgical evaluation for mass effect?
options: Early vomiting, severe headache, declining consciousness
questions.explanation: Posterior fossa edema can rapidly cause brainstem compression/hydrocephalus—requires close monitoring or decompression.

questions.stem: A lacunar 'ataxic hemiparesis' syndrome most often involves:
options: Internal capsule posterior limb or basis pontis
questions.explanation: Ataxic hemiparesis is a classic lacunar syndrome from internal capsule or basis pontis.

questions.stem: Which artery supplies the lateral inferior pons including the facial nucleus leading to ipsilateral facial paralysis and hearing loss when infarcted?
questions.explanation: AICA infarcts can cause facial paralysis (CN VII nucleus) and hearing deficits (labyrinthine artery branch).

questions.stem: Man-in-the-barrel syndrome (bilateral proximal arm weakness) after watershed infarcts occurs between:
questions.explanation: Hypoperfusion can injure ACA–MCA watershed motor regions affecting proximal upper limbs.

questions.stem: Lacunar stroke pathophysiology is most commonly due to:
questions.explanation: Small vessel disease with lipohyalinosis causes lacunes; risk factors include HTN/DM.

questions.stem: Which acute BP strategy is appropriate in ischemic stroke eligible for IV thrombolysis?
options: BP must be ≤185/110 before tPA, then ≤180/105 after
questions.explanation: Guidelines use ≤185/110 pre-bolus and ≤180/105 post-tPA; tighter control risks hypoperfusion.

questions.stem: In ICH with large cerebellar hemorrhage and brainstem compression, best management?
questions.explanation: Large cerebellar ICH with deterioration requires surgical decompression.

questions.stem: A patient has left internuclear ophthalmoplegia and left facial weakness. Where is the single lesion that explains both?
options: Left dorsal pons involving MLF and facial colliculus
questions.explanation: A lesion at the facial colliculus affects the MLF and CN VII fascicles → INO + ipsilateral facial palsy.

questions.stem: Right paramedian midbrain infarct involving the red nucleus causes which syndrome?
questions.explanation: Benedikt: ipsilateral CN III palsy with contralateral tremor/ataxia from red nucleus involvement.

questions.stem: A dorsal midbrain (Parinaud) stroke causes:
options: Impaired upgaze, light-near dissociation, convergence-retraction nystagmus
questions.explanation: Dorsal midbrain syndrome features upgaze palsy and light-near dissociation.

questions.stem: Left lateral inferior pontine (AICA) infarct classic triad includes:
options: Ipsilateral facial paralysis, decreased lacrimation/salivation, and hearing loss
questions.explanation: AICA territory includes CN VII nucleus and labyrinthine artery to inner ear.

questions.stem: Anterior spinal artery infarct at the medulla (medial medullary syndrome) results in:
options: Ipsilateral facial pain loss and contralateral body pain loss
Contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral vibration/proprioception loss, ipsilateral tongue weakness
Ipsilateral facial paralysis and hearing loss
questions.explanation: Medial medullary: corticospinal, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal fascicles involvement.

questions.stem: A patient with acute left hemiparesis has gaze preference to the right and global aphasia. Likely occlusion?
questions.explanation: MCA stem affects both superior and inferior divisions—global aphasia and severe hemiparesis with gaze toward lesion.

questions.stem: Acute onset vertigo, severe ataxia, ipsilateral facial sensory loss, contralateral body pain/temp loss, and hoarseness point to:
questions.explanation: Classic lateral medullary features including nucleus ambiguus involvement (dysphagia/hoarseness).

questions.stem: A patient presents with pure alexia without agraphia and right homonymous hemianopia. Lesion localization?
questions.explanation: Disconnection of visual input to language areas via splenial lesion causes alexia without agraphia.

questions.stem: Hemiballismus after stroke localizes to:
questions.explanation: STN lesions produce contralateral hemiballismus.

questions.stem: A patient has left Horner syndrome, left ataxia, and right body pain/temperature loss without facial weakness. Lesion?
questions.explanation: Face motor nucleus is spared in medulla; combination fits lateral medullary syndrome.

questions.stem: Right MCA inferior division stroke most likely produces which visual-perceptual deficit?
questions.explanation: Non-dominant inferior parietal/temporal cortex → neglect.

questions.stem: PCA infarct of calcarine cortex typically causes:
questions.explanation: Primary visual cortex lesion → contralateral homonymous field loss.

questions.stem: In basilar artery occlusion, which sign suggests rostral brainstem involvement?
options: Vertical gaze palsy with preserved consciousness
Coma with quadriplegia and small reactive pupils
questions.explanation: Basilar occlusion injuring pons causes coma/quadriplegia with small reactive pupils.

questions.stem: A right thalamic VPL lacune produces which deficit pattern?
options: Left body numbness with intact face
questions.explanation: VPL relays contralateral body sensation; VPM is face.

questions.stem: Watershed infarcts after hypotension commonly involve which cortical pattern?
options: Cortical ribbon in ACA–MCA and MCA–PCA border zones
questions.explanation: Border-zone cortical regions are vulnerable to hypoperfusion.

questions.stem: A left superior division MCA stroke is MOST associated with which aphasia profile?
options: Fluent speech with poor comprehension and repetition
Nonfluent speech with intact comprehension and impaired repetition
Severe word salad with intact repetition
questions.explanation: Broca aphasia: nonfluent, relatively preserved comprehension, impaired repetition.

questions.stem: Medial medullary syndrome includes all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Facial nucleus is in pons; hypoglossal in medulla.

questions.stem: A stroke producing right inferior quadrantanopia localizes to:
questions.explanation: Left Meyer loop carries right superior visual field—lesion causes right superior quadrantanopia; inferior requires parietal—thus here 'inferior' is parietal contralateral.

questions.stem: Which vessel supplies the medial medulla?
questions.explanation: ASA supplies medial medullary structures.

questions.stem: In acute ischemic stroke beyond 4.5 hours but with large-vessel occlusion and favorable perfusion mismatch, best therapy?
questions.explanation: Thrombectomy up to 24 hours in selected patients with mismatch/clinical–core criteria.

questions.stem: Aphasias lateralize to which hemisphere in most right-handed individuals?
questions.explanation: Language dominance is typically left-sided.

questions.stem: A patient has acute left leg weakness with urinary incontinence and abulia. Vascular territory?
questions.explanation: ACA supplies medial frontal (leg area), cingulate—abulia/incontinence.

questions.stem: A paramedian pontine infarct causing 'one-and-a-half' syndrome injures which structures?
options: Ipsilateral PPRF/VI nucleus and ipsilateral MLF
questions.explanation: Ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (PPRF/VI) plus ipsilateral INO (MLF).

questions.stem: Which early ischemic changes on CT predict higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation after tPA?
options: Extensive hypoattenuation and sulcal effacement >1/3 MCA territory
questions.explanation: Large early ischemic changes correlate with increased risk.

questions.stem: A 55-year-old with sudden severe headache, neck stiffness, and normal CT at 6 hours. Next best test?
questions.explanation: SAH suspicion with normal CT warrants LP for xanthochromia after 6 hours.

questions.stem: Right PCA infarct affecting the splenium is most likely to cause:
questions.explanation: Right occipitotemporal lesions can cause prosopagnosia; alexia without agraphia requires left splenial involvement.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old with sudden painful Horner syndrome and transient aphasia after running. Suspect:
questions.explanation: Carotid dissection causes ipsilateral painful Horner and anterior circulation ischemia.

questions.stem: Which deep perforator territory is supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries?
questions.explanation: Lenticulostriates from MCA supply basal ganglia and internal capsule.

questions.stem: Balint syndrome (optic ataxia, ocular apraxia, simultanagnosia) results from lesions where?
questions.explanation: Dorsal visual stream bilateral lesions cause Balint.

questions.stem: A lesion in the thalamic VPM most likely affects which modality?
questions.explanation: VPM relays trigeminal (face) sensation.

questions.stem: Lateral pontine (AICA) infarct typically includes which finding? (case 61)
options: Ipsilateral facial paralysis and decreased lacrimation with possible hearing loss
Ipsilateral Horner with nucleus ambiguus sparing
questions.explanation: AICA supplies facial nucleus and inner ear via labyrinthine artery—facial palsy + hearing loss.

questions.stem: Which artery perfuses the lateral geniculate nucleus and optic tract most often implicated in homonymous visual field defects? (case 62)
questions.explanation: Anterior choroidal supplies optic tract/LGN; lesions cause homonymous field defects.

questions.stem: A superior division MCA infarct in the non-dominant hemisphere most likely causes: (case 63)
options: Left neglect with gaze deviation toward lesion
questions.explanation: Non-dominant frontal-parietal regions → neglect and gaze preference.

questions.stem: Pure motor hemiparesis without cortical signs—best initial imaging localization? (case 64)
questions.explanation: Lacunar infarct of IC posterior limb is classic.

questions.stem: A basilar tip aneurysm thrombosis causing bilateral PCA infarcts will most likely present with: (case 65)
questions.explanation: Bilateral occipital infarcts → cortical blindness (Anton syndrome possible).
